title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to exercise in, so itrsquos a shame to see it spoiled by discarded empty bottles, food wrappers and general rubbish.ldquoI kicked off the campaign by nominating three members of our players ndash Aaron McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will nominate other team-mates, and so on.The project has the backing of Selkirk head coach Scott Wight.He said: ldquoItrsquos another way the club can put something back into the local community, though this time therersquos no sponsorship involved.ldquoItrsquos looking asitrsquos going to be a wee while before any rugby is going to be played, so this latest effort not only helps keep the players in touch with each other, itrsquos also providing a useful service for the Selkirk community.Meanwhile, Selkirk Rugby Club is to stage its annual Players Presentation Night on Fridayndash although this yearrsquos event will be a lsquovirtualrsquo get-together.The plan is for the clubrsquos coaches, players and rugby officials to be digitally linked via Zoom, with Selkirk head coach Scott Wight taking charge of proceedings.ldquoThe idea is to try and stick as closely as possible to the format normally used at the clubrsquos annual presentation nights, said Wight.ldquoA total of nine trophies are up for grabs, and the name of each award winner will be announced separately on the video link, followed by film footage, or photos, of that player in a match situation.ldquoShort addresses will be given by, among others, the clubrsquos chairman and its director of rugby, as well as recaps of the st and lsquoArsquo XVsrsquo seasons by the sidesrsquo respective team managers."It should be a fun evening!

title: job-losses-peebles-shop-lifeheal-closes-permanently
story: SIX more workers are losing their jobs in the Borders due to coronavirus.The owners of LeHeal, which sells body and mind treatments, have announced they are closing their clinics in Peebles and Linlithgow.Business partners Sam Hastings and Erica Douglas say the mounting pressure of government regulations and costs of personal protective equipmentmake it impossible to continue.They estimatethat the required protective equipment would cost a four-figure sum each month.In an announcement on the companys Facebook page, Ms Hastings said: ldquoThe challenges for small business owners [are] truly frightening, and as we [sat] down to try and find a way through, we ourselves were shocked and disappointed to discover there is simply no way [forward].ldquoA combination of protection and PPE requirements, accumulated rent and bills, and a forecasted reduction in demand means that financially the mountain to overcome is just too steep.She added: ldquoFrom an aesthetic point of view, itrsquos dficult for us to imagine being able to deliver our usual service and benefits with all the distancing and protection policies.Following a successful five years running their Peebles High Street branch, the business partners invested in new frontage and a micro cafeacute.The company says it will offer departing staff the chance to take kit and equipment should they wish to continue offering their services.Ms Hastings said: ldquoOne of the hardest parts of this is having to let our staff down, but we will endeavour to help them practically and emotionally as we all take this journey together.With LeHeal closing with immediate effect, another dficulty the business faces is honouring purchased vouchers.ldquoTo date we have lost a vast sum in revenue and much of our discussion has been centred around how we will honour these vouchers, said Ms Hastings.ldquoUnfortunately we will be unable to offer refunds, but we will be drawing up a menu of options in the hope that we can make the best of a bad situation.These options include workshops ndash online and in-person ndash and a range of treatments. Ms Hastings added: ldquoWe will do our very best, but we ask for your patience and understanding as we try and work through this.Speaking to the Peeblesshire Newsthis week, Ms Douglas said the decision to close was heartbreaking and many tears have been shed.ldquoWe would like to thank all our clients and the community as a whole," she said."We hope that others in less hands-on industries can weather the storm.

title: eight-famous-film-locations-scotland-can-visit-lockdown-eases
story: SCOTLAND has produced its fair share of top movie stars over the years.But its not just our famous faces that make it to the screen - its our scenery too.Our country has played host to a surprising number of films - from Hollywood blockbusters like Avengers and James Bond, to Scottish favourites like Trainspotting and Outlaw King.With the five-mile limit on travel for leisure set to end in Scotland on July , and hotels set to reopen on July  - weve pulled together alist of the best on-screen locations across the country to visit once lockdown eases.Harry PotterWhere: Glenfinnan, Highlands,The famous Glenfinnan Viaduct features in both the second and third Harry Potter films ndash with the Hogwarts Express even calling at Glenfinnan station.Tourists flock to the area every year for the stunning scenery surrounding the railway ndash perched ft above the ground.SkyfallWhere: Glen Etive, HighlandsJames Bondrsquos epic Skyfall experience saw him in Istanbul, a skyscraper in Shanghai and an abandoned island in Japan.But it was the breath-taking scenes in Glencoe that captured the eye of  fans across the globe.TrainspottingWhere: EdinburghAn iconic film based right in Scotlandrsquos capital, itrsquos almost dficult to NOT find yourself near one of the sets for the Trainspotting films.Almost half the scenes of T were filmed right in the city ndash from Renton and Spudrsquos run around Holyrood Park and Arthurrsquos Seat, to the epic escape from the nightclub through Edinburghrsquos Old Town.And who can forget the original opening scene ndash with drug-afflicted Renton sprinting down Princes Street to the sound of Iggy Pop.Outlaw KingWhere: VariousDiving deep into the legends of one of Scotlandrsquos most important historical figures, it makes sense for a film about a travelling outlaw to be set across ious dferent locations in Scotland.From the Catheral in Glasgow, to Scone Palace just outside Perth ndash there is plenty of Robert the Bruce history to keep you occupied on a tour of the country.Full details of Outlaw King locations can be found here.Avengers: Infinity WarWhere: EdinburghOnce again the capital played host to a major blockbuster film ndash Marvelrsquos Avengers: Infinity War ndash back in .And as the only location outside of a studio to be used in the film, Edinburgh is truly a star of the film.Cockburn Street in the cityrsquos Old Town first appears when Scarlet Witch and Vision stand outside a fast-food restaurant.The Royal Mile then became a thrilling backstop in the film, with convincing explosions and breath-taking action scenes.Avengers: EndgameWhere: St Abbs, BordersOne of the most successful films of all time, Avengers: Endgame also used Scotland as the location for some of its scenes.,params: .pushThe fishing village of St Abbs in the Borders was renamed lsquoNew Asgardrsquo, and saw movie star Chris Hemsworthdescend on the town to film some scenes.According to the local leboat, who have jokingly said the village is now lsquotwinnedrsquo with the fictional village, the filmmakers Marvel made a ldquogenerous donation to the leboat.World War ZWhere: George Square, GlasgowIn ,  cast and crew ndash including Brad Pitt ndash descended on the streets of Glasgow city centre to film the zombie blockbuster World War Z.American cars and street lights were brought in to resemble Philadelphia, the filmrsquos setting.George Square can be seen from  seconds in this trailer here:Where: Govan Graving Docks, GlasgowOscar and Bafta-award-winning war epic  is one of the newer films to be shot in Scotland - but its success is just as prominent as the rest.Co-writtenby GlaswegianKrysty Wilson-Cairns, some of the films most suspenseful scenes come right on our doorstep - with the Govan Graving Docks on the River Clyde used to replicate a war-torn area as the main character battles in arace against time behind enemy territory to try save fellow soldiers from a trap.

title: ridiculed-tourettes-childhood-borders
story: A CHILDHOOD spent receiving unwanted attention left Tourettersquos sufferer and former Peebles High School pupil Jack OrsquoHara with severe anxiety and depression.As the son of a retired police officer and a bank cashier, his le would be relatively normal without Tourette syndrome, a neurological disorder which affects around one in  children and young people in the UK.Now a first-year Scottish history student at the University of Edinburgh, Jacks memories of growing up with Tourette syndrome are still agonisingly fresh.Speaking to the Border , -year-old Jack said: ldquoMy earliest memory of facing adversity was in primary two, when I had a problematic teacher.ldquoShe didnrsquot believe that I had Tourettersquos ndash she thought I was acting up for attention.The memories of being ridiculed at such a young age evidently still haunt Jack today.He said: ldquoI remember the teacher showing me up and making me look like a fool in front of the class."When the teacher laughed, my classmates laughed too.As a youngster, Jack also exhibited bursts of impulsive behaviours ndash on occasions, he would run out onto the middle of the road towards oncoming traffic.After countless visits to his GP, and being wrongly diagnosed with ADHD and autism, he was eventually confirmed as having Tourettersquos at the age of seven.Nearly  per cent of people who seek treatment for Tourettersquos will be diagnosed with a second psychiatric disorder during their letimes, according to researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital.Due to the complicated nature of the syndrome, misdiagnoses are common, and the process of finding a correct diagnosis for Jack took several years.And although the rest of his school days were slightly easier and his school was cooperative, Jack faced other issues.Undertaking a series of drug trials from the ages of eight to , he lost three stone in a year ndash making him dangerously underweight.ldquoThe medication made me feel so low and lethargic all the time and came with horrendous side effects," he said.ldquoI had no personality and was reduced to skin and bone."One gave me breasts, and one made me drool all the time.A  study in Biological Psychiatryrevealed that Tourettersquos sufferers are four times more likely than the general population to die by suicide, with mental health problems having a ldquosevere impact on their daily lives.With the constant attention being directed towards him due to his physical and vocal tics, Jackrsquos own mental health took a turn for the worse during secondary school.When using public transport, Jack would always sit at the back to avoid all eyes being on him.Most of his tics are quite physical, which meant his anxiety would sky-rocket when he was out in public.After being diagnosed with generalised anxiety disorder and depression, even leaving the house became too much at times.ldquoTourettersquos infiltrates every part of your le, Jack said.ldquoIt got to the stage that every time I left the house, I would come back crying because of bullying or horrible comments.ldquoMy main problems arenrsquot because of my tics. Theyrsquore because of public reaction and public perception of Tourettersquos.ldquoThe fact that Irsquom ticking doesnrsquot make me depressed and it doesnrsquot make me anxious."Itrsquos how other people react. Itrsquos only such a huge part of my le because of other people.ldquoItrsquos instinctive for people to turn around and look, but it doesnrsquot take away from the fact that it makes me feel uncomfortable and embarrassed over something that I cannot control.It was not only the tics that made Jack stand out from the crowd during childhood.As a gay teenager, he says he struggled to make any male friends because of his sexuality, which he has never hidden.And the struggles, although manesting in dferent forms, have continued into young adult le.As a result of years of relentless twitching and involuntary leg movements, Jack is battling chronic muscle pain and nausea.Cognitive behaviour therapy reiki reflexology ndash Jack has tried everything to relieve the pain but to little avail.He is prescribed strong painkillers, and at times has had to keep his neck in a brace because of his tics.,params: .pushWhen attempting to enter bars or nightclubs, bouncers sometimes reject him because they believe he is under the influence of illegal drugs.Alcohol consumption can trigger his tics, making them more prominent and frequent.Even in university lectures, he sometimes must call out people for continually turning around and staring at him, despite knowing his condition.Jack insists that suffering from Tourette syndrome has given him a ldquothick skin".He has always felt fully supported by his parents but has chosen to be independent from a young age, refusing to let his condition prevent him from doing the things he wants to achieve.Attending doctors appointments on his own from the age of , Jack preferred to handle everything by himself.In his third year at Peebles High School, Jack ran a public campaign and was successfully elected as a Member of the Scottish Youth Parliamentfor the region.He said: ldquoI ran because Irsquove always been interested in social issues and wanted to meet like-minded people, which I sometimes felt starved of growing up.ldquoI think I would be a really confident, extroverted guy without my tics ndash they are the one thing holding me back.Since his darkest days battling anxiety and depression, Jack has made friends andhad part-time jobs in bars in Peebles and Edinburgh.Mental health struggles may have stolen parts of Jacks childhood ndash and he continues to live in the spotlight of Tourettersquos ndash but it hasnrsquot stopped him embracing student le.

title: primary-school-galashiels-records-bruno-mars-cover

title: air-bridges-destinations-might-included
story: Travellers couldbe jetting off abroad on quarantine-free summer holidays soon - withthe UK Government set to announce so-called air bridges to popular destinations.Since March , the Foreign and Commonwealth Office advised British nationals against all but essential international travel.Now, a number of short-haul flights to European countries are expected to resume from next month in a bid to kick-start the tourist economy.This is what you need to know about air bridges and travelling abroad.What are air bridges Also known as travel corridors, air bridges will allow Britons to go on holiday to certain destinations without needing to quarantine for  days on theirto the UK.Which countries are likely to be included The Government is expected to announce next week Britainrsquos first air bridges with ldquolow-risk European destinations, including France, Italy, Spain, Greece and Germany.According to reports, air bridges will be announced in batches, with the second set of destinations likely to include other European countries such as Denmark, Norway, Finland and Holland and ldquolow-risk Caribbean islands.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said air bridges would only be agreed with countries which have a coronavirus test and trace system of the same standard as that used in Britain.When will air bridges be introduced The first air bridges to low-risk countries could be in force from July , but Mr Shapps said no announcement will be made until June  when the quarantine measures will be officially reviewed.Which countries are unlikely to be included There were mixed reports over whether Portugal would be included in the UKrsquos plans next week after a spike in coronavirus cases in the country.Long-haul flights to destinations such as Vietnam, Singapore, Hong Kong are reportedly not expected before late summer.Flights to Australia are thought to be more complicated due to the need to stop over in other countries, which increases the risk of contracting or spreading coronavirus.What are the rules on quarantine Since June , all passengers ndash bar a handful of exemptions ndash have been required to go into self-isolation for  days when they arrive in the UK.People who fail to comply can be fined pound, in England, and police are allowed to use ldquoreasonable force to make sure they follow the rules.What measures have airports taken Last month, Heathrow Airport began trialling thermal screening technology to detect elevated temperatures of arriving passengers.Edinburgh Airport has implemented a colour-coded one-way system to maintain social distancing, while protective screens have been installed at check-in, security and arrivals, and staff wear face coverings and personal protective equipmentin ldquopassenger-facing areas.At Gatwick Airport, hand sanitiser stations, protective screens, regular deep cleaning and social distancing instructions have been introduced throughout the site, with face mask vending machines selling four masks for pound.Pre-booked airport security slots are being trialled at Manchester Airport, in which passengers can reserve a free -minute window to use a dedicated lane taking them directly to a checkpoint.

title: find-man-king-street
story: HAILED by their neighbours as the gardening ldquoKing and Queen, a Peebles couple have spent decades transforming the grass verges on their street into an attractive wildle haven.lsquoIf you want something done right, do it yourselfrsquo ndash an age-old adage that was brought to le by Brian Elliot and his we Lynne.The King of Kingsway, , moved to the street in .When Scottish Borders Council stopped cutting the steep grass banking outside his home, he and his neighbour Billy Duncan rolled up their sleeves and got on with the job.That was  years ago, and Billy has since moved, but green-fingered Brian continues to develop the plantation garden, with many comparing it to the beauty of Dawyckrsquos botanical garden.If the display were in the running at the prestigious RHS Cha Flower Show, judges would go wild for the attractive shrubs and nectar-rich flowers, which grab the attention of bees and butterflies.But Kingswayrsquos Monty Don has not only created a garden that is pleasing to the eye, he has also built a home for wildle.ldquoOver the years Irsquove planted a iety of shrubs, trees and bushes and flowers and put bark down," he said."Itrsquos a great habitat for insects which encourages birds."We get lots of butterflies, bees and itrsquos a wee haven for hedgehogs."Itrsquos just lovely hearing the birds singing and the bees buzzing."The -year-old says his nature reserve is appreciated by many in the town.Having created the garden and maintained it for  years, we asked Brianit is a labour of love.He laughed: ldquoI donrsquot like gardening ndash itrsquos a chore."At least thatrsquos what I tell people when they stop to speak."Neighbours and locals passing by do appreciate it, which makes it worthwhile.The garden, which spans over  metres, hasnrsquot cost Brian an arm and a leg ndash just his big toe!ldquoIt was  years ago. Irsquod just come back from holiday and had my sandals on."I went out to cut the grass and slipped down the banking and cut off my big toe, he explained.ldquoIt was my own stupid fault. I shouldrsquove put my safety boots on. I learned a valuable lesson that day.Brianrsquos efforts were recognised in  when he received the Letime Achievement Award from Peebles in Bloom.You could call Brian the king of lsquoungardeningrsquo. Rather than creating a controlled environment with a perfectly manicured lawn full of chemicals and pesticides, he has brought back the beauty of wilderness and reversed the ecological decline.He has built a home for the local wildle which has Peebles residents and birds singing in symphony.

title: six-new-things-can-today-scotlands-lockdown-eased
story: FURTHER easing of lockdown measures in Scotland continues today.The First Minister last week confirmed an acceleration of easing restrictions across the country following a continued suppression of the virus.But Nicola Sturgeonhas since urged the public not to ldquosquander that progress as we move into more freedom.Here, we detail out the six changes taking place today:Shopping and outdoor marketsOne of the most anticipated announcements from lockdown, non-essential shopsare now officially allowed to reopen.The one restriction still in place, however, is these must be street-access retail. Non-essential stores within shopping centres malls must remain closed until Phase .Commenting on the re-opening this morning, the First Minister tweeted: ldquoIf you plan on visiting shops today, please do so responsibly.ldquoMaintain physical distancing, follow hygiene advice, wear a face covering and respect staff who may be asking you to shop dferently.ldquoWersquove made so much progress against the virus ndash letrsquos not squander it. #StaySafe.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.On Friday, First Minister @NicolaSturgeonset out guidance on how to #StaySafewhen some shops reopen today following changes to #coronavirusmeasures.Find out more ## https:t.co DwqbXAFMkpic VVuUhPzZmdash Scottish GovernmentJune , WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .This does NOT include indoor workspaces that are due to open in Phase  ndash like non-essential offices and call-centres.Moving homeFrom today, all home moves are permitted, provided they can be carried out safely.This includes students moving home and other home moves resulting in two households merging.It also applies to custom and self-builders looking to acquire a plot or a property to renovate or to demolish.The Scottish Government has issued guidance around this ndash as well as encouraging people to take part in virtual property viewings as much as possible with further guidance around health and safety here.Outdoor sports courts and playgroundsFrom today, outdoor sports courts can reopen to the public.This includes courts for tennis, basketball, volleyball , Multi-Use Games Areasand netball.Participants must maintain strict physical distancing at all times when using outdoor sports courts. This does not include pitches used for contact sports.,params: .pushPlaygrounds can also reopen.These were closed at the start of lockdown amid fears the virus could spread through the physical contact in these areas.Marriages and civil partnershipsMarriages and civil partnerships can resume from today.These have to have a minimal number of attendees and, despite the Scottish weather, be outdoors only.All the participants, including the couple and the witnesses, must come from no more than three households and will be possible up to amaximum of eight.The celebrant or registrar will not count as one of the households.Zoos and garden attractionsMust to the anticipation of those in Edinburgh, zoos and garden attractions can open from today.However the Scottish Government guidance says these are initially for local access only ndash meaning people broadly within five miles can attend.Increased hygiene measures are encouraged, with pre-booking tickets online also advised.

title: lynx-marmite-create-new-fragrance---can-get
story: Marmite and Lynx have teamed up to create anew aroma that issure to ignite a furious debate.The new flavour has been created "for all the lovers", according to Lynx Brand Manager Jamie Brooks.He described Lynx Africa  Marmite as the combination of "two iconic legends that have shaped dating and breakfast culture across the nation".What does it smell of The perfume itself is said to contain "aromatic notes of lavandin, white moss, and green herbs, along with woody profiles of creamy sandalwood and cedarwood ndash unexpectedly met with a slightly salty punch of Marmite".Where and when can I get it Lynx Africa  Marmite will be available as both a deodorant and body wash.The ml Body Spray will retail at pound., while the ml Body Wash will set you back pound..Most UK leading supermarkets and drug stores will stock the products from Wednesday, July .But isnt there a Marmite shortage Though its combination with Lynx may cause even the staunchest Marmite loved to turn their noses up, it may be the only chance theyve had to lock nostrils on its distinctive smell in recent weeks.Thats because in the UK, Marmite has proven particularly tricky to get hold of due to the coronavirus crisis.Unilever, which owns the brand, said in early June that it had temporarily stopped producing all pack sizes of the product other than its small g jar.The brand confirmed the news on social media, stating that the temporary measures were due to brewerrsquos yeastbeing in short supply.Responding to a fan keen to find one of its larger g squeezy jars on Twitter, Marmite said: ldquoDue to brewers yeast being in short supplysupplies of Marmite have been affected.ldquoAs a temporary measure we have stopped production of all sizes apart from our g size jar which is available in most major retailers.The brand has since announced production levels are back to normal, meaning fans should see the full range of jars back on supermarket shelves shortly, including g and g jars.

title: really-special---craig-lowrie-reflects-galashiels-run

title: avoid-fleas-ticks-dogs-summer-heatwave

title: film-fans-enjoy-upgraded-galashiels-cinema
story: FILM fans in the Borders will soon enjoy an improved cinema in Galashiels.The Pavilion Cinema, on Market Street, is upgrading its sound system after receiving a pound, grant towards the cost of work.Pavilion manager Andrew Poole said: ldquoWe canrsquot wait to hear the dference this makes to the sound quality in all four screens and wersquore extremely excited to be able to share that with our customers when we do reopen.The cinema secured cash from The National Lottery through Screen Scotlandrsquos Cinema Equipment Fund.High-quality equipment is being installed, some of which will help customers who are visually impaired or hearing impaired.Mr Poole said: ldquoWersquore extremely grateful to Screen Scotland for this funding which will enable us to transform our audio provision for all our customers.ldquoIn the current economic climate, we wouldnt have been able to embark on such an ambitious project without this vital support.ldquoFilm is an immersive experience and a filmrsquos soundtrack is  per cent of that experience.ldquoItrsquos vital that we continue to offer our customers the very best experience we possibly can.ldquoThe current sound system in the Pavilion does a good job, but it couldnrsquot be described as cutting edge.Screen Scotlandrsquos Jenner Armitage said: ldquoWhen we launched the Cinema Equipment Fund last year, we had no idea what  was going to bring, but investing in the resilience of Scotlandrsquos film exhibition sector is more important than ever.ldquoWhen Scotlandrsquos cinemas reopen, they will be able to offer high-quality experiences, with ied programmes, and within local communities.Mr Poole says the developments will include the following upgrades:Replacing all sound processors with Dolby CP Cinema Sound Processors enabling Dolby . sound in all four screensReplacing all ampliers with QSC DPA Cinema AmpliersReplacing all speakers with QSC Cinema SpeakersInstallation of a Dolby Fidelio system in all four screens

title: tescos-hidden-message-shoppers-receipts
story: Eagle-eyed shoppers have uncovered an important message that appears on every Tesco receipt.So why is it there  And what have Tesco said about it  Heres what you need to know.What is the story behind why the message is there Domestic violence cases have risen by an estimated per cent since the beginning of lockdown.While the number of cases has spiked nationwide, many victims are still unsure as to what they can do and where to gofor help and support.Since the harrowing figures were released,Tescohasdecided to stepin andhelp in the battle against domestic violence.What does thehidden Tesco receipt message say The message - located at the bottom of Tescos receipts - reads: "Help is availableyoure experiencing domestic abuse."Call the National Domestic Abuse helpline on   . Download the Brightsky App."What has Tesco said about the hidden message A Tesco spokesmansaid: "Domestic abuse affects  in  women and  in  men during their letime."By using our till receipts to provide information on where victims of domestic abuse can access support, we hope that more people will be able to get the help they need.What has the response been like from shoppers Many whospotted the message have praised the supermarket chain for sharing the details in such a subtle way.Shoppers took to Twitter to share their praise for the idea.One shopper tweeted:"Shoutout to Tesco for putting the national domestic abuse helpline on all their reciepts."Another tweeted: "Im really impressed to see this on the bottom of my@Tescoreceipt today."Very subtle, safe way of getting information and options to victims of domestic abuse, who might be the people that do the household shopping."This has the potential to help a lot of people."Another posted on the social media : "Good on Tesco including this on their receipts."

title: new-rules-viewing-houses-scotland
story: PROPERTY viewings are allowed again in Scotland - but new rules are in place.The Scottish Government relaxed the restrictions on visits on Monday, June .However, people are being encouraged to wear face coverings and they are advised to avoid touching surfaces.ESPCrsquos chief executive officer Paul Hilton said: ldquoProperty buyers and tenants looking to move home will be pleased that physical viewings are now permitted.ldquoIn the last couple of weeks, ESPC has noticed increases in viewing requests for properties for sale, which are signicantly up compared to last year. ldquoThe viewing process is dferent to before COVID- and it is important that all parties involved adhere to the health and safety guidance from the Scottish Government.This is the full list of guidance from the Scottish GovernmentInitial viewings should be done virtually wherever this is possible and property agentsand landlords should help you to do thisAll physical viewings should be arranged by appointment only and open house viewings should not take place. You should not view any propertiesyou have COVID- symptoms or are self-isolatingWhen physically viewing properties, where possible, you should avoid touching surfaces, wash your hands with soap and water before entering the property or use alcohol-based hand rub The number of people attending a viewing at one time should be restricted so that physical distancing can be practised. You should only be accompanied to viewings with members of your current household and or your property agent, social landlord or private landlord or representative.If you need to be accompanied by young children, you should try to stop them touching surfaces and ensure they wash their hands regularlyIf people are being shown around or working in your current home, while you are still living there, you should open all internal doors and ensure surfaces, such as door handles, are cleaned before and after each viewing with standard household cleaning productsWhere possible, we recommend that you vacate your property whilst viewings are taking place, unless you are conducting the viewing. This is in order to minimise your contact with those not in your household when moving between properties, you and those in your household should try to do as much of the packing yourself as you can.Where this is not possible, you should speak to removal firms in advance. There is further advice about this belowIf you are particularly worried about the risk of infection, then speak to the professionals involved, your landlord, letting agent, property agent or removers as they may be able to put in place extra measures

title: rare-lunar-eclipse-visible-glasgow-weekend---need-know
story: SKYGAZERS across Scotland will be treated to a rare penumbral lunar eclipse this weekend.One of only eight to occur this decade, all eyes will be on the skies early on Sunday morning.Here, we bring you everything you need to know ahead of the penumbral lunar eclipse.What is it A penumbral lunar eclipse takes place when the moon moves through the faint, outer part of earths shadow.Why do lunar eclipses happen A lunar eclipse happens when the Earth comes between the sun and the moon, therefore blocking some or all of the sunrsquos light from reaching the moon.Therefore, the moon cannot shine ndash because its surface is not reflecting the sunrsquos rays.The eclipse will be visible over ScotlandWhat makes this eclipse dferent According to TimeAndDate, a penumbral lunar eclipse occurs when the sun, earth and moon are imperfectly aligned.When this happens, the earth blocks some of the sunrsquos light from directly reaching the moonrsquos surface, and covers all or part of the moon with the other part of its shadow.Where should I look People in Scotland are urged to find an unobstructed area with a free sight to the southwest for a best view of the eclipse.When can I see it Unlike solar eclipses, which can only be seen along a narrow path from a small part of the earth, eclipses of the moon can be observed all across the night side of earth when the eclipse title: dismissed-workers-accuse-borders-branch-unfair-treatment
story: A BUSINESS faces an employment tribunal following allegations by dismissed workers.TheBorder reported last week that LeHeal, which sells body and mind treatments, would be closing its clinics in Peebles and Linlithgow.Business partners Sam Hastings and Erica Douglas said the mounting pressures of government regulations and costs of personal protective equipmentmade it impossible for them to reopen their high street branches.The owners said six staff members would lose their jobs at the Peebles branch, adding that the workerswould be supported ldquopractically and emotionally.However, some of the dismissed workerssay they were dumbfounded after reading LeHeals statement. They are claimingthey were unfairly treated by their former bosses.One dismissed staff member gave a long list of allegations, adding: ldquoTo read what was being said by them [LeHeal] on Facebook, it felt like a slap in the face.The former workersare now taking their ex-bosses to an employment tribunal which will take place at a hearing in Glasgow on Wednesday, July .LeHeal co-owner Ms Hastings said: ldquoWe have answered a request by the court to explain our decision-making throughout this crisis and we are confident wersquoll be found to have acted as best we could amid the chaos.

title: pictures-remembering-princess-diana-scotland-59th-birthday
story: PRINCESS Diana would have turned  years old today.The Princess of Wales won the hearts of many Scots during hervisits north of the border.She was widely called "the Peoples Princess" due to hercharity work, her sense of style and her dedication to sons Prince William and Prince Harry.The respect she garnered across the country was put on full display following her tragic death in , with thousands of mourners paying tribute in Princes Street Gardens in Edinburgh and George Square in Glasgow.Here, we take look back at some of Princess Dianarsquos most memorable moments in Scotland.The Princess of Walesat the Braemar Highland Games on September .Princess Dianas visit to Malcolm Sargent house, Prestwick, September .Princess Dianaat Rottenrow Maternity in the early s.Prince Charles points out someting of interest to Princess Diana at the Braemar Highland Games inSeptember .Princess Diana is presented with a bunch of white heather at the Braemar HighlandGames inSeptember .Prince Charles and Princess Diana on a tram at the Glasgow Garden Festival in .Princess Diana meets the people of Possilpark during a walkabout after her visit to the Possil Drugs Project in .Princess Diana at the opening of the Prince and Princess of Wales Hospice in Cathcart.The Queen, the Queen Mother, Prince Charles and Princess Diana at the Braemar Highland Games in .Princess Diana at the Maryhill community centre in Glasgow in .Prince Charles and Princess Diana at the Glasgow Garden Festival opening in .

title: peebles-shops-celebrate-reopening-3-months-lockdown
story: The rain hammered Tweeddale on Monday , but it failed to dampen the spirits of the Peebles shopkeepers who opened for the first time in three months.On Tuesday morning Border reporter Hilary Scott spoke to the retailers who are back in business, while photographer Helen Barrington captured their smiles.Despite a large number of locals wearing face masks, the town of Peebles is ghostly no more.As Scotland eases gently out of lockdown, businesses are tentatively opening their shops ready for a new way of working.A limited number of customers are allowed within the townrsquos quaint shops, social distancing remains in place, and hand sanitiser and protective screens abound. It is the dawning of a new era for shopkeepers as they fight to keep their businesses afloat during the coronavirus pandemic.Among the businesses open is menswear retailer Graham McGrath, the long-established family-run business.Owner David McGrath said: ldquoDespite the rain yesterday we had a good first day. There were a few folk out and about and we got to catch up with customers that had ordered things before lockdown."Therersquos a bit of buzz about the town and itrsquos great to be back.The owner of the Gt Box, Stephanie Morrison, has been busy throughout lockdown due to her role as deputy manager of the Peeblesshire Foodbank, alongside her husband James.But staff member Lucy McKenzie was behind the cash register ready to greet customers with a smile.ldquoIt feels very strange to be back, but wersquore so pleased to be open again," she said.Meanwhile the owner of Brevity Fashion Boutique, Eleanor Mabon, feels like shersquos never been away.ldquoI was so surprised at how busy it was because I thought nobody is going to come out in this weather," she said."I think folk were just glad to get out of the house and thought, Well, Irsquove stayed in the house for three months, Irsquom going out now regardless of the weather.ldquoI canrsquot say I havenrsquot enjoyed the rest but it is back to business."I have a one-way system which works well but folk are used to social distancing now ndash they know what to do.Staff at Fine Rogerson Footwear had their PPE gear on and had the first customer through the door at am on Monday.ldquoWe had our first sale just after am," said manager Kath Traynor. ldquoWe had more male customers than normal which shows deep down they do want to shop!"Wersquove been doing all the necessary cleaning ndash you could eat your dinner off this floor."Some fishy business pulled us away from the shoe shop and it wasnrsquot the smell of feet.Ross Dougal Fish Merchant took a gamble and decided to continue trading throughout the lockdown.It was a gamble that paid off, though, according his daughter Brooke.,params: .pushShe said: ldquoWe were worried to start with because we have to get our stock in fresh every week and we didnrsquot know how it was going to go."But we ended up being really busy with a lot of local support so itrsquos been a relief.ldquoItrsquos amazing seeing the town busier because itrsquos been like a ghost town apart from a little queue outside our shop and at Forsyths.Further along the street we popped into Keith Walter Jewellers. Despite bumping into the clear protective screens every now and then, staff member Patricia Ovejero, says shersquos happy to get back to some normality.She said they have been kept busy doing small jobs for customers like changing batteries and watch straps.Across the road, there was a socially distanced queue forming outside the newly fitted-out cafe and takeaway Dellarsquos.Della Murray and her partner Artur Budenko came out to have a chat with us.ldquoWe closed on the first week of lockdown," said Della, "and then we bumped into a few of the locals and key workers who said they couldnrsquot get anything to eat so we decided to open back up."We had a chat with environmental health who guided us through what we needed to do to stick to regulations."Asked their thoughts on some shops opening back up, Della replied: ldquoItrsquos just fab. Wersquove been lonely and missed them all, so it was nice to see them all back yesterday.ldquoWe have been very fortunate as a high street regarding business losses."It is our first anniversary in a fortnight and it has been sink or swim for us."Wersquove kept fairly busy through this period, but itrsquos all testament to Arturrsquos food ndash I canrsquot take credit for that.The town of Peebles isnrsquot quite as bustling as it once was, but locals have heard the rallying cry from their high street to lsquoshop localrsquo.And as long as people keep this in mind, shops and businesses in Peeblesshire will go from surviving to thriving.

title: primark-owner-hails-encouraging-early-sales-lockdown
story: Primark owner Associated British Foodshas said sales at the high street retailer have been ldquoencouraging after reopening sites, despite predicting a major hit to profits.ABF said the chain has been boosted by strong sales of childrenrsquos clothes and leisurewear but that sales for the past quarter plummeted % to pound million as a result of the virus pandemic.The consumer group said total sales across its isions had fallen by % to pound. billion for the quarter to June , compared with the same period last year.It said signicantly lower sales at Primark, which has no online operations, were partly offset by growth in its grocery and ingredients arms.ABF said only eight of its  Primark stores have not yet reopened, while it has reported ldquoreassuring and encouraging trade from stores which have welcomed customers again.Customer demand has also been strong for summer clothing such as shorts and T-shirts, while sales of formal menswear and travel-related accessories have been ldquounsurprisingly weak, it said.In a statement, the company added: ldquoMost of our regional stores are performing well, especially in retail parks.ldquoOur stores in the centre of big cities are suffering from the current absence of tourism and much lower commuter footfall.It said sales in the first week of reopening in England and Wales were ldquoahead of the same title: uk-aerospace-industry-disappear-unless-government-acts---unite
story: The UKrsquos world-class aerospace industry will be lost forever unless there is urgent action to support the sector through the current crisis, a leading union is warning.Unite said its research revealed that almost , aerospace job losses have been announced in recent months at some of the UKrsquos biggest companies, including , by Airbus earlier this week.The union said it has repeatedly warned that without swt action to support the aerospace industry, more jobs will go on a ldquovast scale and the UKrsquos crown as an industry leader will be ldquostolen by competitor countries.A study for the union showed that , workers are directly employed in the aerospace sector, with many thousands more in indirect employment.The sector has a turnover of more than pound billion, generating over pound billion for the UK economy every year.Unite said it wanted the UK government to follow the lead of countries such as France and Germany and put in place a programme the sector needs to survive, rebuild and recover.Unite assistant general secretary Steve Turner said: ldquoUnless we see comprehensive action to support UK aerospace now, then this world-class industry could well be lost on the Johnson governmentrsquos watch. There is not a moment more to be lost.ldquoThis is a sector that generates billions for the national coffers, helping fund our NHS, public services and the Governmentrsquos promised infrastructure spend. It supports jobs theand breadth of the country and is central to UK national security.ldquoAerospace is exactly the sort of high-skilled industry, based in the communities that need to be at the heart of the Prime Ministerrsquos promised levelling up efforts.ldquoThis is a flexible, committed workforce. It stepped up during this crisis, manufacturing ventilators and other equipment desperately needed for the NHS and to protect the public. They deserve so much more than a government that turns a deaf ear to requests for assistance.ldquoWhile aerospace workers in France and Germany are being embraced by their government, kept in decent paid work, working a shorter working week and retraining in preparation for the upturn, playing their part in building a greener, stronger economy, our governmentrsquos inertia will see thousands of jobs lost and more of our business move overseas.Mr Turner warned that recent job losses will ldquosnowball into an avalanche of further redundancies without help.A Government spokesman said: ldquoWe understand this is a dficult time for businesses and workers across the aerospace sector and stand ready to support those at risk of losing their jobs.ldquoThe aerospace sector remains a critical part of the UK economy and we will continue to work closely with industry to ensure it can rebuild as the civil aviation market recovers.ldquoWhile conditions remain challenging, firms can continue to draw on the Governmentrsquos financial support packages, including billions of pounds of loans and guarantees, tax deferrals and the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: UK aerospace industry could disappear unless Government acts  u Unite

title: county-rugby-club-given-1-000-boost
story: Dunbar RFC has been given the four-figure sum by Persimmon Homes Building Futures scheme.The initiative will see poundmillion given away across Britain to regional charities, groups, sports clubs and schools to improve local facilities and the delivery of vital community projects for people aged under .Dunbar Rugby Football Club is the first recipient of the recently launched initiative and supports more than  people under the age of .The club works closely with primary and secondary schools to encourage young people to play rugby in a safe and enjoyable environment.The club plan to use the funds to replace fencing that surrounds the main pitch at Hallhill Sports Centre.Building Futures aims to support community groups working with under-s across three categories ndash education and arts, health and sport.In addition to hundreds of local donations of pound,,  initiatives will go on to compete for top prizes of pound, through a national online public vote.Laura Still, sales and marketing director for Persimmon Homes East Scotland, said: ldquoWe are proud to support Dunbar Rugby Football Club, who offer a valuable opportunity for young people to develop new skills and boost confidence.ldquoWith so many chances to win vital funding for their projects, we urge charities, schools and sports clubs to apply online before May .

title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be able to have crowds as well but I am really not sure what the rules on that are going to be yet ndash whether it is crowds or played behind closed doors, it would be a bit oddit was behind closed doors."In general, we will have to wait and see what the rules are about crowds."That is what produces the benefit in the short-term to the local economy."Mr Findlay highlighted that the tourism sector had taken "a huge hit" during the coronavirus crisis and many businesses would have to survive until next year before tourism started to resume in the traditional way.Currently, the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is pencilled in for August - at the same venue.Last yearrsquos event was won by Mi Jung Hur.

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: opinion-nitrous-oxide-no-laughing-matter
story: AS WE approach the traditional school holidays and perhaps some nicer weather, I once again make a plea to all parents and carers of children and young people to make sure you know where they are, who they are with, and ensure they are not engaging in anti-social behaviour.In recent weeks, with lockdown easing, we have seen large gatherings of youths, sometimes more than  at a time, at ious locations around the county.The vast majority of these are all well behaved but a small minority have been engaging in signicant anti-social behaviourand disorder.North Berwick, Tranent and Longniddry have caused us some issues recently, with intoxicated youths verbally abusing passers-by, vandalising items, smashing bottles and leaving a mess behind. This is not acceptable.East Lothian Countryside Rangers have reported a signicant rise in rubbish, empty alcohol bottles, broken tents and ious other items on our beaches and parks.When you visit the coastal areas, you expect it to be clean, tidy and safe, and the Rangers do an exceptional job keeping up with the disgusting mess left behind.However, what they are now regularly cleaning up is way beyond what should ever be expected.During a clear up at Longniddry Bents last week,  canisters of nitrous oxide, or laughing gas, were found discarded, along with hundreds of empty alcohol bottles. This appears to be a trend amongst youngsters, to get a temporary high, and as a parent of two young girls I find this extremely concerning.You may see these small finger-sized silver canisters in parks or discarded in the street.I wanted to provide some information on this gas to help you understand the risks so you can explain these to your children.Inhaling the gas slows down messages between the brain and body, causing temporary feelings of calmness and joy.Negative effects can include dizziness, headaches or fainting. It can also cause confusion and cloud judgement. Sometimes the user can see or hear things that arenrsquot real. The risks include it preventing the ability to breathe and, in extreme cases, death.It can cause the heart rate to beat irregularly, increasing the risk of heart failure, and heavy use has been linked to vitamin B deficiency which can cause nerve damage. The user can also become confused and panicky, which may lead to accidents.This is not something we want our children and young people experimenting with. This is a gas that dentists and medical professionals use under controlled conditions to sedate patients for minor medical procedures.I have arranged a multi-agency meeting to raise awareness of the risks and to prevent someone from becoming ill, injured or dying from this.Please talk to your children and discuss the dangers of these canisters and the impact of ASB.Eventhey havenrsquot been part of the group, they may know who has. Please report any concerns to us on the  number, or  in an emergency.If we all work together we can improve our communities and keep our children and young people safe.

title: letter-week-tribute-east-lothians-retiring-msp
story: Iain exemplies the very best in public service.His motivation and his hard work have always been about improving the lives of others.During his career at Holyrood, his contribution in health and social care, and in education, have helped improve the quality of le, and le chances, of many.I have had the privilege of seeing that work first hand, sharing an office with Iain in Tranent for five years.Iainrsquos values extend beyond his politics to the way he lives his le, and the way he responds to people.He is a great person to have as a colleague and friend.As well as being generous with his experience and advice, we shared many laughs. In more dficult times, he was equally generous with his support and understanding and I will always be grateful to him for that.For Iain, putting East Lothian first has been so much more than a line in a leaflet.He loves our county and has been an enduring supporter of local communities, organisations and businesses.I hope this doesnrsquot read like an obituary, in a political or any other sense.I have no doubt that he will work hard for us in the lead up to the Scottish Parliament in May , and beyond that he will continue to make valuable contributions to political discourse in Scotland, and to make a dference here in East Lothian.Through your letters page I want to thank Iain for his years of public service in East Lothian, and on a personal note to thank him for his constant friendship.We are all very fortunate to have such a man in our lives.Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell

title: gallery-open-doors-first-time-two-months
story: Fidra Fine Art was forced to shut on March  due to coronavirus-related restrictions.However, with restrictions being eased, Alan Rae, from the gallery, was pleased to say a new exhibition would be unveiled on Monday .Mr Rae told the Courier: ldquoWe will be following government guidance relating to social distancing and public safety and so, to begin, with we will restrict access to one person or family group at any one time.ldquoAs we were unable to access the gallery space we decided to postpone, until next year, our lsquoIdiosyncraticrsquo exhibition, featuring the work of Mark Bannerman, Joseph Davie, Alan Macdonald, Alice McMurrough and Gordon Mitchell.Instead, the gallery, which was previously based in North Berwick, is getting ready to move the Mixed Summer Exhibition from online to lsquoin the fleshrsquo.Mr Rae added: ldquoI am delighted that the artists from the "Idiosyncratic" exhibition have still been able to submit a number of pieces and will be exhibiting alongside a whole host of cracking artists, so far confirmed are: George Birrell, Dominique Cameron, Matthew Draper, Michael Durning, Neal Greig, Andy Heald, Whyn Lewis, Neil Macdonald, Rachel Marshall, Heather Nevay, Ann Oram, Paul Reid, David Schofield, Astrid Truumlgg, Graeme Wilcox and Christopher Wood with ceramics and sculpture from Andrew Adair and Arran Ross.ldquoIt really is a great line up of some of the most popular and interesting artists working in Scotland today.ldquoThe exhibition covers a wide range of styles and genres and is sure to appeal to art lovers starved of creative visual art during lockdown.The exhibition opens at am on Monday and runs until August .

title: letter-yellow-lines-road-coastal-car-park
story: Tyninghame is often very busy at weekends and in the holidays, with cars parked outwith the paid parking spaces on the road, not to avoid paying but because the car park is full ndash we have often had to do this ourselves.So we were very disappointed on ing this evening to see that, while the car park has been closed due to lockdown, the council has painted double yellow lines for . miles from the edge of the car park along the entry road.This means that, unless you want to add . miles to your walk, only  families or groups can access the woods and links at any one time.Given that it is a vast site, with woods and one of the biggest beaches in East Lothian, this seems a very strange decision.Irsquom sure we wonrsquot be the only people who think this is an unreasonable action to take.Surely they could just have extended the payment zone Or is this a calculated decision to raise revenue from parking tickets issued to those who risk parking on the linesthe car park is full, rather than walk . miles Name and address supplied

title: shielding-dad-runs-half-marathon-back-garden
story: Stephen Ferguson, , who has asthma, undertook the challenge as he is lsquoshieldingrsquo during the Covid- lockdown after receiving advice from the NHS.He is no stranger to half marathons, having completed three in the past ndash Glentress Trail, Edinburgh and Stirling.This time round, he took his treadmill outside at his home and finished his lsquogardenrsquo half marathon ndash . miles ndash in one hour,  minutes and  seconds.His efforts have so far raised around pound for First Step, which supports families with young children.Mr Ferguson, who works with the Royal Bank of Scotland in Haddington, lives on Musselburghrsquos Galt Crescent, near First Step in Galt Avenue, and was inspired to take on the fundraising challenge as his three-year-old son Cormac enjoys attending its nursery.His we Louise also attended baby classes there with Cormac.Originally from Omagh, in Northern Ireland, Mr Ferguson has lived in Scotland since October , and married Louise last October.He also has a stepdaughter, Aaliyah, .He was helped with his training by Junior Burton of JB Combat Bootcamp, Wallyford, who was there to cheer on Mr Ferguson from a safe distance.Mr Ferguson said: ldquoThe run was really good. title: alasdair-northrops-debut-book-shares-tales-tourist-guides
story: Alasdair Northrop spent the past  months researching and writing Guiding Lights: A History of the Scottish Tourist Guides Association -.It tells the story of the Scottish Tourist Guides Association, which celebrated its th anniversary last year.Alasdair qualied as a blue badge tourist guide in  and quit his job as a journalist to go full-time in .He later joined the board of the Scottish Tourist Guides Associationand became chair of its marketing committee.When he learned that STGA would be celebrating its diamond anniversary last year, he suggested writing a book about its history.He said: ldquoI started researching its history in autumn , going through old committee papers and newsletters and interviewing some of the older guides.ldquoI then did a talk about its history at our th anniversary AGM in March last year but I had still not finished the book.ldquoOnce the tourist season was under way I could not do any more work on it until November last year.ldquoThe coronavirus crisis resulted in the cancellation of all my work this year and I have used some of the time to finish off this book.ldquoIt has been a fascinating project and I discovered there was a lot to write about.He added: ldquoOne of the purposes of the STGA was to create lsquoprofessionalrsquo guides who not only learned about Mary Queen of Scots but who also knew how to make sure a large group of tourists didnrsquot get run down when crossing a busy road!ldquoNot surprisingly,you are writing a book about tourist guides there are some really interesting tales to tell.ldquoAmong them is the story about how a guide took Prince Edward and his friends on an incognito tour of Edinburgh Castle, where the royal family member queued with everyone  to see the Crown jewels.Today, STGA has more than  active members, a number of whom live in East LothianAlasdair said: ldquoAs I am a member of the board I am not allowed to make any money from the book so all the proceeds are going to the association, which is very useful at this particular time.ldquoI hope the book will be of interest to anyone involved in the history of Scottish tourism and there are some very amusing stories in it for the general reader.Alasdair said he was looking forward to the reopening of Scottish tourism next month.He added: ldquoI am an optimist by nature, and you can be sure we will see tourist guides .ldquoNew skills and new ways of working will be required and I am confident members of the Scottish Tourist Guides Association will meet that challenge.The book is available as an ebook on Amazon, and Alasdair hopes to see it in print one day.

title: opinion-need-wind-change-says-mp
story: WESTMINSTER voting arrangements may be farcical, but parliament still affords an opportunity to question ministers.I asked the business secretary about grid transmission charges. As offshore wind increases in scale and importance, itrsquos here that much of its energy lands. Cockenzie and Torness are transmission points, eventurbines are sited out at sea.Therersquos room for many more, and the scale of the turbines is far bigger than those onshore, causing less aggravation yet producing more power. Scotlandrsquos ideally placed to benefit, with our weather ndash which we often curse ndash being to our advantage. Itrsquos reckoned that  per cent of Europersquos wind resource blows off our shores.That should be a blessing, being clean and plentul. But ensuring that we benefit is what matters. At the moment grid charges, dictating the cost of transmitting energy, mitigate against sites in Scotland and the north of England. Itrsquos perverse as thatrsquos where theyrsquore located yet itrsquos made most expensive to locate or produce from here.As I said to the Tory minister, Scotland missed out on its oil and gas wealth. As we now, rightly, have a renewables revolution, it cannot miss out again. Not just these renewable energy resources but the onshore manufacturing jobs are badly needed.More widely, many constituents were in touch about the UK Governmentrsquos plans to merge the Department for International Development into the Foreign Office. I share their concerns and am raising them.Organisations such as SCIAF, who I know well, rightly point out that it should be about addressing the needs of people and assisting developing countries, not promoting British foreign policy. This is a moral argument, not an administrative arrangement. Whatever challenges we face, the plight of others is far worse.Finally, I wish Iain Gray well. Our paths have crossed in Holyrood and now here. Wersquove disagreed on Scotlandrsquos constitutional situation but have agreed on much more. Hersquos a man of principle and has served the constituency well.

title: mediator-services-solve-lockdown-conflict
story: Robin Burley, an Inveresk resident, and Malcolm Currie, from Musselburgh, are supporting a new mediation service launched across Scotland with help from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Wellbeing Fund.Conflicts can include a personal relationship that is under duress as a result of self-isolation or a dispute with an employer about ing to work during the Covid- outbreak.Anyone is eligible for the service : they live in Scotland the conflict is connected to social distancing or self-isolation it is not part of a pre-existing dispute, for example, orce proceedings or formal contact arrangements and all of the people in the conflict agree to participate in mediation.Provided by a group of professional volunteer mediators, the service is free to iniduals and organisations with up to five employees.Organisations with more than five employees will be charged pound for up to one dayrsquos mediation. The service can be accessed through the Scottish Mediation website or by emailing admin@scottishmediation.org.uk.Mr Currie founded Strathesk Resolutions after more than a decade working as a trades union negotiator.Engaging with employers in the private, public and third sectors, he developed his expertise in collective bargaining, dispute resolution and tackling complex inidual cases.These skills were built on a foundation of over  years advising and influencing countryside managers in relation to land management and pulling together funding packages from wide-ranging sources for joint projects.He has helped organisations as erse as aircraft engineering, academic research institutes, heritage bodies and charitable trusts to establish effective workforce consultation mechanisms, and to operate them to the greatest effect for company performance.Mr Currie said: ldquoAs with any disagreement or dispute,we arenrsquot able to have a conversation about it andit remains unresolved, the frustration that can create can end up being greater than the original reason why there was a disagreement.ldquoThat can often have impacts on mental health and wellbeing so it is goodpeople are able to speak about whatrsquos happening.Mr Burley has been mediating for  years, having carried out more than  mediations which draw on his mediation training and  years of work and le experience in housing, community care and organisational governance.His mediation practice has developed with its focus on civil justice mediation, employment, workplace, commercial, construction, property, urban, rural, agricultural and complaints.He initially trained with Core Solutions in  and, after taking a degree course in mediation and conflict resolution at Strathclyde University, he gained a masterrsquos degree with distinction in .He stood down from six years as chairman of Scottish Mediation in .Prior to working as a mediator and coach, he spent  years in housing and care services and urban development.He was chief executive of the Edin Group, a past chair of Blackwood, ELCAP and the Built Environment Forum Scotland .He has also held non-executive director positions with NHS Lothian, Queen Margaret University and the Scottish Federation of Housing Associations.Mr Burley commented: ldquoMediators are able to help create the space for that conversation in a way which allows the parties to use creative ways of resolving disagreements and in some instances to repair relationships, too.ldquoIn terms of what might be a suitable dispute for mediation, we will be able to speak to you about your dispute and advise on each instance.ldquoAs a general guide, the sorts of disputes include those around family matters, including care of older relatives, flatmates housemates, landlord tenant, co-operative or social housing, workplace concerns related to working from home or shared workspaces and those involving neighbours.ldquoIt is possible that some issues may have existed before and were being managed successfully but the additional pressures have pushed them into conflict.Graham Boyack, director of Scottish Mediation, added: ldquoThis is a challenging time for everyone and the isolation and stress of living in close quarters can cause, or increase, conflict for families, friends, and roommates, and can create challenges for work teams, charities and businesses.
